Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Environmental Subject Formation at the Intersection of Hydraulic Fracturing and Agricultural Production: A Critical Q Study of the Twin Tiers Region

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rapid rise of shale gas development via hydraulic fracturing is reshaping rural regions of the United States in significant and uneven ways. This project will analyze how human-environment interactions within agricultural landscapes are being reshaped by the introduction of hydraulic fracturing, as farmers decide whether or not to permit shale gas development on their land. In this way, the project responds to a pressing need for scientific research on the impacts of the hydraulic fracturing boom on farmer-landowners in the US. The study will produce new insights about how farmers act as environmental citizens in relation to state-level shale gas development policy, land grant college extension programs, and the production of environmental knowledge. Working at the interface of political ecology, science and technology studies and Q methodology, the study will move beyond simplistic representations of the complex practices of shale gas development and lay the groundwork for building consensus by identifying areas of convergence between farmer-landowners representing different orientations to hydraulic fracturing. The doctoral student will work with local land grant colleges to share the research findings at regional agricultural conferences and with diverse stakeholders in the shale gas development debate.

This project employs a mixed methods approach to analyze farmer perceptions of hydraulic fracturing. The central research question asks: How are human-environment relationships being reconfigured at the intersection of hydraulic fracturing and agricultural production? The research will examine the Twin Tiers region of Pennsylvania and New York as a case study to examine how divergent state-level policies may impact perceptions of hydraulic fracturing. The doctoral student will use Q methodology, a method of statistically analyzing subjective viewpoints, to identify how farmers experience hydraulic fracturing on their land. The use of Q methodology will also identify areas of convergence that may be used to build consensus among diverse stakeholders in the hydraulic fracturing debate. These findings will be supplemented with interviews to provider greater depth and detail while interpreting the results of the Q method study. Additionally, the doctoral student will use critical discourse analysis to examine how social contexts impact the ways in which human-environment interactions are shaped. These findings will inform local stakeholders, land grant colleges, and policy makers by highlighting potential areas of consensus between opposing viewpoints on hydraulic fracturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes Report

PI: Hilda Kurtz

Co-PI: Gretchen Sneegas

NSF Award #1656309

 Since the mid-2000s, shale gas development via hydraulic fracturing – known colloquially as fracking – has been a process increasingly used to extract natural gas from shale rock formations deep beneath Earth’s surface. This dissertation examines whether and how fracking is reshaping human-environment relations, focusing specifically on the relationship between shale gas development and agricultural production.

 To date, much scholarly research on the topic of shale gas development has focused on perceptions of risk and harm. The practice remains highly controversial among some groups: pro-drilling advocates view it as beneficial for the economy and national energy security, while anti-fracking activists argue that it contributes to climate change and may permanently degrade vital environmental resources such as water. However, relatively few studies have examined the degree to which shale gas extraction is impacting farming and farmers’ perceptions of shale gas development. To examine this relationship, the project’s Co-PI chose as a case study site the Twin Tiers region – which includes the Northern Tier of Pennsylvania and the Southern Tier of New York. The Twin Tiers region sits within the Marcellus Shale Basin, a shale rock formation stretching beneath much of Pennsylvania, New York, West Virginia, and Ohio that is estimated to have the largest recoverable shale gas reserves in the U.S. While over 10,000 hydro-fracked wells have been drilled in Pennsylvania over the past decade, the practice has been de facto banned in New York since 2008. These two states provide a timely and compelling case study to better understand how farmers are responding to the introduction of fracking to agricultural landscapes, and the degree to which the practice is impacting human-environment relations in the region.

 To do so, this project employs a “worldview mapping” approach, with 49 participants in the Twin Tiers region asked to rank-order a series of statements relating to the relationship between shale gas development and agricultural production. The participants included farmers across a range of sizes, products, and practices (e.g. conventional and organic), as well as Cooperative Extension agents, land grant college researchers, municipal policymakers, and both pro- and anti-drilling activists. The Co-PI statistically compared the individual responses using a form of factor analysis that identified how individuals sorted the statements along similar patterns, forming clusters of participants who share related worldviews. The analysis identified four key shared worldviews: 1) Cautious Supporters, 2) Shale Gas Adversaries, 3) Extraction Enthusiasts, and 4) Anti-Government Skeptics.

 While the analysis is not yet fully complete, the following findings and themes have emerged:

 First, the identified viewpoints do not neatly align with state boundaries – each worldview includes both Pennsylvania and New York residents. Instead, each worldview appears to be more closely aligned to structural position/employment and political ideology. Cautious Supporters (11 participants) include the majority of land grant college and Cooperative Extension employees, and is the most diverse in terms of political ideology. Shale Gas Adversaries (14 participants) include farmers using non-conventional, non-commodity production (e.g. organic, small-scale, local sales) and anti-fracking activists, and the majority describe themselves as politically liberal/progressive. Extraction Enthusiasts (11 participants) include primarily farmers using conventional, commodity production (i.e. use of pesticides and fertilizers, sold products through regional agricultural markets) and the majority describe themselves as politically conservative. Lastly, the Anti-Government Skeptics (7 participants) are all farmers, the majority of whom use non-conventional, non-commodity production methods, and all of whom describe themselves as politically conservative or libertarian. Nine participants were not affiliated with an individual viewpoint at a level of 48% statistical significance.

 Second, a critical discursive analysis of the public debate around shale gas development and farming in the region identified a key pro/anti-fracking dichotomy which shapes how this topic is viewed and discussed, and in turn limits what solutions are possible or feasible. In popular media portrayals of hydraulic fracturing, the practice is discussed as either good for the economy, or bad for the environment. This project argues that depicting shale gas development through this lens reduces the topic’s complexities and erases viewpoints and the potential for consensus between seemingly opposing positions. As the identification of at least four distinct worldviews indicates, this bipolar discourse influences, but does not fully determine, how residents in the Twin Tiers view the relationship between fracking and farming. Instead, the analysis views the pro/anti-fracking discourse as a product of uneven power relations that is reinforced and employed by different stakeholders to further their purposes and support their positions. As the analysis continues, it will continue to examine how this bipolar discourse was created, why it endures, and how it continues to shape perceptions of shale gas development and farming.
